channel.title: Combined Politepol Feed
channel.description: Merged feed from multiple Politepol sources

item.title: Now Trump seen with purple bruise at Davos. Why do these marks keep appearing?
Who is Liam Ramos, 5-year-old detained by ICE in Minnesota?
Why are Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose’s ashes still in Japan?
Will Trump’s ‘framework deal’ mean more US troops in Greenland?
How Nato chief Mark Rutte has emerged as the ‘Trump whisperer'
FirstUp: Japan PM to call snap elections, Minneapolis to mourn Renee Good... The headlines today
‘Madman diplomacy’: Trump didn’t break the system, he exposed it
item.description: Donald Trump did not invent the chaotic style of leadership. But he dragged it back into the open, platformed it, stripped it of its subtlety, amplified it through social media, and made it the official gospel of the most powerful nation-state in the world

item.title: Iran is not fighting for liberalism: How feminism is misreading the moment
item.description: The future Iranian woman is not a liberal mascot or a religious subject. She is a political adult refusing to be managed. That is what frightens the clerical state

item.title: The Donroe Doctrine: How Trump’s Greenland gambit signals return of US imperialism
item.description: From Venezuela to Greenland, Washington’s new strongman diplomacy is reshaping global power politics, and India must watch closely

item.title: When power knows no bounds: How Trump’s imperial ambition is upending rule-based global order
item.description: The global order today faces a major challenge from a country that until recently propagated a narrative of ‘democracy and rule of law’

item.title: When Canada looks east: Carney reaches out to China amid Trump’s tantrums
item.description: For much of the past decade, Canada’s China policy has been constrained by its deep economic and security integration with the United States. Donald Trump’s policies have upended that.

item.title: Is Trump bluffing on Iran or serious? History has a lesson for him
item.description: If the decades-long animosity with Iran has taught the US anything, it is that interference in the Islamic Republic’s internal or foreign affairs backfires
